speaker: Maggie
text: [_v.o:_] It's not that I don't like him, Dr. Crane: it's just that he's got so attached to me.  Roses every day for a week after two dates!

speaker: Frasier
text: Maggie, the first thing you have to do is sit Gavin down for a nice long conversation. [_Frasier notices Roz shaking her head_] A frank and honest discussion, tell him that though he wants to go at one speed you need to go at another. [_Frasier notices Roz shaking her head again_] Tell him you're not rejecting him and that you're fond of him but if he doesn't give you some breathing room... you know, suddenly I wonder what Roz, my non-PhD holding producer thinks you should do?

speaker: Roz
text: Well, I just think that any guy that's that clingy after two dates has a major insecurity problem.  I say dump him now: head to the hills and don't look back.

speaker: Maggie
text: [_v.o:_] It's so good to hear that, Roz. [_Frasier is surprised_] That's what I wanted to do but I felt so guilty.  Thanks so much, bye. [_hangs up_]

speaker: Frasier
text: And that takes us to commercial.  This, for those of you that may have forgotten, is the [_angry:_] "Dr. Frasier Crane Show!"

speaker: Roz
text: Here's your new parking pass.  I confirmed your dinner reservations for three; at your father's request you'll be dining at "Chez Shrimp."

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh!

speaker: Roz
text: There are two letters that you've got to sign: a card for Clarence the guard that we're all signing, and a letter for the sign-ups for the KACL bowling team - I'll file this right in the trash. _Roz exits the studio.  Frasier looks at the card.  It's in the shape of a big teddy bear._

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh wonderful, another card.  Of course, I, as resident wit here, will have to think of something clever to say.  Well, at least I've got another gala KACL birthday bash to look forward to.  I can just taste that frozen Sara Lee cake right now, whilst, on applause, a full-grown adult snuffs out a handful of tiny candles!

speaker: Roz
text: What are you grousing about?

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh nothing, nothing.

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, the pageantry never stops. _FADE OUT  Scene Two - Taxi Cab A lady (Arleen) is driving Frasier, Martin and Niles home.  They are in heavy traffic and car horns can be heard all over._

speaker: Martin
text: Mr. Fancy-pants!  You've gotta buy a German car!

speaker: Frasier
text: It's not my fault it broke down.

speaker: Martin
text: Hey, if you bought American, they wouldn't have to tow your car halfway across the state to get it fixed.  That's why I always buy American. Breakdown, you can drive to the nearest garage.  I could break down all alone in the middle of Alaska...

speaker: Frasier
text: Finally a thought to raise all our spirits!

speaker: Niles
text: This traffic is murder.  I'd suggest we walk home but I'm afraid what the humidity will do to these loafers.  Does calfskin pucker?

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, Niles!  That's why on humid farms, the calf is the most made-fun-of of all the animals!

speaker: Niles
text: There's no point in being snide.  We're all going to be in here for a while, we might as well try and make pleasant conversation.  We are a family, after all, it shouldn't be that hard. _There is a long silent pause. Then Martin starts up talking... to Arleen._

speaker: Martin
text: So, you been driving long?

speaker: Arleen
text: Not really.

speaker: Martin
text: I bet you have some pretty good stories, though?

speaker: Arleen
text: You guys ever hear of a woman having a baby in a cab? _The three kid about and ad-lib "yeahs" and "we've all heard that one."_

speaker: Martin
text: Why, did it happen in this cab?

speaker: Arleen
text: No, I think it's about to.

speaker: Martin
text: [_shocked:_] You're pregnant!

speaker: Arleen
text: Yes. [_begins screaming in labor pains_]

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, don't panic, it may just be false labor.

speaker: Arleen
text: My water's just broken!  I'm sitting in a puddle of water.

speaker: Niles
text: Calfskin, calfskin!

speaker: Frasier
text: Niles!

speaker: Martin
text: I think the closest hospital is First Methodist.

speaker: Frasier
text: Dad, we'll never make it in this traffic.  I think we better pull over.

speaker: Niles
text: Please try to park facing down hill.

speaker: Frasier
text: Niles!

speaker: Arleen
text: I can't have my baby here!

speaker: Frasier
text: All right, there's no reason for you to be concerned.  You're in the presence of two trained medical professionals.  [_then_] Niles, help the woman.  _Niles gets out of the cab.  He opens her door and she falls out. After much screaming he pushes her back in and closes the door._

speaker: Frasier
text: No, Niles!  The other door. _Niles goes to the other door and gets into the cab.  Meanwhile, Martin picks up the squawk box._

speaker: Martin
text: Is anybody there?  Come in!

speaker: Niles
text: All right, the most important thing you can do right now is breath deeply.  Just do as I do.

speaker: Frasier
text: Are you feeling faint or out of breath?

speaker: Niles
text: [_hyperventilating_] Yes, both of those.

speaker: Man
text: [_v.o:_] Hello, go ahead.

speaker: Martin
text: Yeah, I'm calling from cab number... 804. This is an emergency.  Your driver, Arleen, just went into labor. We're at the corner of 14th on Sycamore.  We need an ambulance here right now, do you hear me?  Over.

speaker: Man
text: [_v.o:_] Yes, I'll get right on it.

speaker: Arleen
text: Ah, it really hurts.

speaker: Niles
text: It's okay, it's natural.

speaker: Arleen
text: No, you're squeezing my hand!

speaker: Frasier
text: Get a hold of yourself, Niles!

speaker: Niles
text: I'm sorry, I only did this once before in medical school. And all I remember is a bright light, lots of blood and then a linoleum floor hurtling towards my forehead.

speaker: Arleen
text: You fainted!

speaker: Niles
text: Oh, switch places with me, honey, and see how you do!

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, Niles get out of there.  I'll help her.

speaker: Arleen
text: The baby's coming now!

speaker: Frasier
text: If it does come, I'll be here to catch it.  Now listen, just continue with your breathing. [_she does_] Now, I don't want you feeling guilty for having your baby in a cab.  No, there's nothing to be ashamed of.  I'm sure many great Americans have been born this way.  Cab Calloway comes to mind.  My particular area of medicine is psychiatry and I like to specialize in the head, you know, not the lower portion of the body - it's much less messy that way.  Not that your lower half is messy at all, it's quite beautiful... not that I'm looking! [_she screams_] It's hurting a bit?

speaker: Arleen
text: No, you're driving me crazy! [_chucks a cap at him_]

speaker: Arleen
text: What, are you a doctor too?

speaker: Martin
text: No, I'm a retired cop.

speaker: Arleen
text: Well, what took you so long?

speaker: Martin
text: Everything's going to be just fine, sweetheart.  Now I've delivered more than a few babies in my lifetime and some of them are even older than you are now.  Now, Frasier's going to hold your hand and help you with your breathing.  And Niles is going to look out for an ambulance and I'm going to get ready to bring your beautiful baby into this world.  Okay?

speaker: Arleen
text: Okay.

speaker: Martin
text: Now, are there any questions?

speaker: Niles
text: Yes, should our meter still be running?  _Martin and Frasier gives him a look as Arleen screams with another labor pain and throws up a hand that knocks Niles out cold.  FADE TO:  Scene Three - Frasier's Apartment On the dining room table, Daphne's bathrobe is laid out._

speaker: Daphne
text: [_o.s:_] Hello?  Are you back yet? _When there is no answer, Daphne rushes in wearing just a towel and her shower shoes.  She picks up her nightgown to put it on. However, at that moment the Cranes enter.  Daphne, half out of her towel,  holds the robe in front of her, seemingly naked behind it.  Niles gapes, and even Frasier and Martin are stunned._

speaker: Daphne
text: Well go on, turn your heads. _Daphne turns round to change.  The three men turn round 180 degrees and face the wall -- however, Niles continues turning until he is back where he started - staring at Daphne.  Frasier puts a stop to it and turns him back just before Daphne can catch him.  She's ready._

speaker: Daphne
text: Okay.

speaker: Daphne
text: So, I guess you've had some excitement tonight.

speaker: Niles
text: [_the wrong end of the stick:_] No, I haven't!

speaker: Daphne
text: Well, your father sure made it sound exciting on the phone. Delivering a baby in a taxi.

speaker: Niles
text: [_realising:_] Oh, that.  I don't think of that as excitement as much as my sworn duty to use those skills I honed in medical school.

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, Niles ran down to a falafel stand for a pot of hot water.

speaker: Martin
text: What I can't get over is that feeling of being there right when a person's life begins.  One minute it's just this blob in some lady's stomach, next minute it's a person. [_visualizing:_] Blob - Person!

speaker: Frasier
text: The miracle of birth summed up in one poetic phrase.

speaker: Daphne
text: I bet you have some fond memories of when your son was born.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh yes, of course.  I remember the very first time I held him in my arms as a newborn.  And it was as if everything in the universe simply melted away.  There was just a father, a son and the distant sound of Lilith saying, "If you ever come near me again, Frasier, I'll drop you with a deer rifle."

speaker: Martin
text: At least nowadays fathers get to see their sons being born. In my day, they stuck us all in the waiting room, smoking cigarettes and reading "Life" magazine.  I still remember the exact article I was reading when Niles was born.  It was about Mickey Mantle.  Talk about life setting you up for a fall!  Well, it's been a long night.  I'm turning in.

speaker: Frasier
text: Night, Dad.

speaker: Daphne
text: I can't wait to see what kinds of dreams I have after all this talk about childbearing.  Probably that one where my mother shows up and says, [_imitating old woman:_] "Well, Daphne, you're fifty now and you've never given me grandchildren." [_normal voice:_] Then I say, "That was my choice to make, Mum, I was thinking of my career." [_mother's voice:_] "Oh sure, your career, but did you ever think of me?" [_normal, getting carried away:_] "Mother, I don't want to start this again, just drop it." [_old voice:_] "But will she drop it?" [_normal:_] "Oh shut up, mother!" [_old voice:_] "Don't talk to me like that, young lady..."

speaker: Frasier
text: I wonder how many more people she's got in there with her. [_pause_] Sherry, Niles?

speaker: Niles
text: No, thank you.

speaker: Frasier
text: You seem awfully reflective, is something on your mind?

speaker: Niles
text: Actually, yes.  For the past several months I've noticed my thoughts often drifting to the same subject: will I ever be a father?

speaker: Frasier
text: Ah.

speaker: Niles
text: There are pros and cons, of course, but watching that child's birth tonight I realise it's something I really want... I think.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, it's perfectly natural to have parental stirrings around at your age.

speaker: Niles
text: Uh, er, no, this is more than stirrings.  I wake up nights thinking about it.

speaker: Frasier
text: Have you talked this over with Maris?

speaker: Niles
text: Not yet.  I like to know what I want before Maris tells me. I'm just not sure I'm really ready for fatherhood.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, Niles, no-one's ever really sure.  You know, in schools these days, teenagers who are thinking about becoming parents are given a ten-pound sack of flour to keep with them for a week as though it were a baby.

speaker: Niles
text: [_laughs_] You're kidding?

speaker: Frasier
text: No, no, no, they hold it, they care for it, they never let it out of their sight.  It gives them a very good idea of the cost and responsibility of being a parent.

speaker: Niles
text: Hmm, that's very clever.  What could be better than hands-on experience?  Might be worth a try.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, I wasn't actually suggesting.

speaker: Niles
text: Well, why not?  It's the perfect week: Maris is away, I'm desperate to resolve the issue; Frasier, where do you keep the flour?

speaker: Frasier
text: In the kitchen.

speaker: Niles
text: [_excited:_] In the kitchen.

speaker: Frasier
text: The cabinet next to the sink.

speaker: Niles
text: [_opens cabinet and gets out a pack:_] Yes!  Here it is. [_reads_] Extra refined. [_to Frasier:_] It's taking after his old man all ready!

speaker: Frasier
text: No Niles, that's the sugar.  If we're going to do this, we're going to do it right.

speaker: Frasier
text: Now, here is the flour. [_reads_] Bleached, one hundred percent fat free, best when kept in an airtight container. [_to Niles:_] It seems this one's taking after its mother.  _END OF ACT ONE  ACT TWO_  **FLOUR CHILD**  _Scene One - Caf e Nervosa. Frasier is sat at the table when Niles enter with his bag of flour to his shoulder._

speaker: Frasier
text: Hello, Niles.

speaker: Niles
text: Hello, Frasier, may I join you?  Or should I say, may we?

speaker: Frasier
text: _Mais oui._

speaker: Frasier
text: I see you're still continuing with our little baby experiment.

speaker: Niles
text: Yes and it's turned out to be quite a learning experience. It's not easy, though.  I take him everywhere.  Get up for two a.m. feedings, the whole exhausting nine yards.

speaker: Niles
text: What a beautiful baby, how old is he?

speaker: Mother
text: Eight weeks.

speaker: Niles
text: Oh, great age isn't it?  _Niles turns his "flour child" round and we see that he has two plasters on._

speaker: Frasier
text: Niles, I can't help noticing that your child has a little boo-boo.

speaker: Niles
text: Oh, it's nothing.  I was playing him some Brahms the other night, never too early to ingrain them.  I guess I must have begun conducting with one of the gilded chopsticks Maris wears in her bun and I accidentally ran him through.

speaker: Frasier
text: What young parent doesn't tell that story?

speaker: Niles
text: The scars were just plain carelessness.  The fault of my new houseman, Guy.

speaker: Frasier
text: What did Guy do?

speaker: Niles
text: No, no, [_next to the same pronunciation:_] Guy.

speaker: Frasier
text: Guy.

speaker: Niles
text: Back of the throat, Guy.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, who cares?

speaker: Niles
text: He had just given my car the most brilliant shine when I sat the baby on the roof and down it went, down the windshield and onto the driveway.  Will you watch him for me while I order?  _Frasier nods.  Niles lays the new-born on the chair and goes to the counter.  Then Roz enters, and notices the sack._

speaker: Roz
text: Hey, Fras.  Is this seat taken? [_points to chair with flour_]

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, actually... [_catches himself:_] No.

speaker: Roz
text: [_sits_] You'll be happy to know that Clarence is doing a lot better.  I just dropped his card off.

speaker: Frasier
text: Clarence?

speaker: Roz
text: Yeah, Clarence the guard.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, down at the station, Clarence, oh yes, good.  I didn't know he was sick.

speaker: Roz
text: You signed his get-well card.

speaker: Frasier
text: You mean that wasn't a birthday card?

speaker: Roz
text: No, he's in the hospital having a kidney transplant.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh my God, I thought it was his birthday.  I wrote, "Dear Clarence, you're not getting older, you're just getting closer to death"!

speaker: Roz
text: How could you think it was his birthday?

speaker: Frasier
text: I don't know, I guess I just didn't recognise the traditional card for a man in an advanced state of kidney failure was a giant pink bunny rabbit.  Do you think he's read it yet?

speaker: Roz
text: No, I don't think so.  He was sleeping when I left.

speaker: Frasier
text: I'm going to look like a callous fool.  We've gotta get back down there and get that card back.

speaker: Niles
text: [_enters_] How can you be leaving? [_notices baby:_] I asked you to baby-sit!

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, Niles!  I don't have time to stand here and listen to your insanity, I have to go and steal a get-well card from a kidney patient! _Niles picks his son up and nurses it as the radio star and producer leave.  FADE TO:_ **NO GUTS, NO GLORY**  _Scene Two - Frasier's Apartment Daphne and Frasier are reading the get-well card._

speaker: Daphne
text: What does that say?  Geb?

speaker: Frasier
text: [_looks:_] No, no, it's "get." [_reads_] "Get well soon, love Andrea."  Just copy it down, move onto the next name.  _It then becomes apparent that Frasier and Daphne are copying the names from the old card onto a new, identical card._

speaker: Frasier
text: We'll have to transfer all the old names from this card onto the new card, as quickly as possible, I want to get it back there tonight.

speaker: Daphne
text: So you actually snuck into a man's hospital room and stole his card?

speaker: Frasier
text: I did not sneak in!  Luckily, the man was in extreme pain and heavily sedated.

speaker: Martin
text: This never would have happened if you had taken the time to find out who this Clarence guy was!  You never pay any attention to the little people in your life.

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, well as soon as we're done with this, why don't we invite all the commoners over to drive me down to the town square and give me a good stoning! [_doorbell_] That must be Niles.  He's going to take me down to the hospital. _Frasier opens the door to Niles. He is stood with a wide smile on his face and his flour child hanging from him in a baby carrier._

speaker: Frasier
text: Hello Niles. [_notices_]

speaker: Niles
text: Hello Frasier.

speaker: Martin
text: What are you doing with that thing?

speaker: Niles
text: I'm forging a parent-child bond that will last forever.

speaker: Martin
text: Well that's a relief, I was afraid it might be something stupid!

speaker: Niles
text: If it makes you feel any better, I don't wear this in public, I just wanted to get the complete picture of parenthood.

speaker: Frasier
text: And?

speaker: Niles
text: It's driving me batty! _Niles sits down and knocks the what-would-be head of the baby against the table._

speaker: Niles
text: Oh the feedings every two hours.  Constant monitoring where he is, I can see how parents can be obsessed with worry.  Last night, I actually had a dream my flour sack was abducted and the kidnapper started sending me muffins in the mail.  Well, on the plus side, I've learned a lot. I think if I ever undergo through the real thing I'll make quite a wonderful parent.  _Niles lifts it out of its pouch revealing to us that it is in fact burnt to a crisp._

speaker: Frasier
text: Niles!  What has happened to your child?

speaker: Niles
text: I was practicing my Tai Chi exercises this morning and I accidentally kicked him into the reflecting pool.  That's when I brought him inside and left him by the hearth to dry.

speaker: Frasier
text: He caught on fire?

speaker: Niles
text: It's not as careless as you make it seem.  After all, a real child would have cried before it burst into flames!

speaker: Niles
text: Oh, time for his nap.

speaker: Niles
text: Turn him over if he starts fussing, will you, dad?

speaker: Martin
text: No.

speaker: Niles
text: I'm role playing, dad.

speaker: Martin
text: Try playing the role of a sane person.

speaker: Frasier
text: So Niles, any closer to making a decision about fatherhood?

speaker: Niles
text: To tell you the truth, no.  At one minute I think there's no chance in hell I'll ever be able to stand the stress.  The next I find myself daydreaming about taking my son on his first trip to the museum or listening to him pick out his first feeble "F�r Elise" on the piano and I swear there are tears in my eyes.  _Frasier notices that Eddie has begun ripping Niles's son to bits. Flour is all over the couch._

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, dear.

speaker: Niles
text: What?

speaker: Frasier
text: Eddie.

speaker: Daphne
text: [_Australian accent:_] That dingo's got your baby!

speaker: Niles
text: Oh God, Eddie!

speaker: Daphne
text: Don't worry, I'll clean up that mess, Dr. Crane.

speaker: Niles
text: Oh my God.

speaker: Martin
text: For God's sake, Niles, calm down.  I think it's time you realized something.  That is not a person, it's a bag of flour.  There's an easy trick to tell the difference: people don't usually come with pop-over recipes on their backs. This whole thing's stupid.  We're talking about having a baby here.  You don't make that decision intellectually, you make it in here. [_points to his chest_] In your gut.  You must have a gut feeling, Niles - what is it?

speaker: Niles
text: I'm not sure.

speaker: Martin
text: Well, you better be because no amount of thinking can prepare you for what having a kid is really like.  It's hard, full of surprises.  Like maybe your kid won't want to take piano lessons or go to the museum.  He might want to go to a baseball game.

speaker: Niles
text: Don't even say that.

speaker: Martin
text: Just trust yourself, son.  That's all.  You'll know if it's right or not.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_picks card up:_] Well, Niles, I'm finished with this now, if you're ready to take me to the hospital.

speaker: Niles
text: You know Frasier, I'm beginning to wonder if this whole experiment wasn't just a way of convincing myself that I'm ready for something when I know in my heart, I'm not.

speaker: Frasier
text: What do you mean?

speaker: Niles
text: I want to have a baby, but I just don't want it enough. That's the hardest thing I've ever had to admit.

speaker: Frasier
text: Why do you say that?

speaker: Niles
text: Oh, because it's so selfish.  I'm the right age, I have the money, the energy.

speaker: Frasier
text: Niles, it's only selfish when people have babies for the wrong reasons. I think more people should do what you did and find out if they're really ready.  Look, just because you feel this way now doesn't mean things can't change a few years down the line.

speaker: Niles
text: Perhaps you're right.  Of course, Maris and I will be over forty then.  Maybe it wouldn't hurt to look into getting some of her eggs frozen.

speaker: Frasier
text: Ooh, I suspect they're only a few degrees away from that now.  _Frasier and Niles exit.  FADE TO:  Scene Three - Hospital Corridor Niles and Frasier are walking down the corridor of the hospital._

speaker: Niles
text: You're certainly going to a lot of trouble for this Clarence fellow.  Who is he?

speaker: Frasier
text: Beats me.  Some guy down at the station.  _Frasier enters the room with the patient in.  The old man is in bed fast asleep.  Frasier notices get-well cards strung across a string above the man's bed so opens the card to put it with the rest. However, upon opening the card the music strikes up.  Frasier quickly puts the card up and the whole string falls down covering the sleeping man in cards.  Meanwhile the music from the card puts a finishing touch to the scene.  Frasier quickly hurries out slamming the door behind him. When he gets out, Niles has gone, and he comes face to face with an old man walking along the corridor.  This man is the real Clarence.  He is walking with his wife, Mary._

speaker: Clarence
text: Dr. Crane!  It's Clarence.  You weren't in there looking for me, were you?

speaker: Frasier
text: As a matter of fact I was, yes.

speaker: Clarence
text: They changed my room. Mary: Oh, this is so sweet of you.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, you know, Clarence is such a fixture down at the station.  I just haven't felt the same there without him.

speaker: Clarence
text: You find the time to come down here while the rest of those bums at the station don't even send me a card.

speaker: Frasier
text: Gee, Clarence, there's an explanation for that... _Frasier opens the room he just went in and offstage we hear the music and a man screaming, "Make the music stop!" Frasier quickly shuts the door._

speaker: Frasier
text: You see, the others at the station, they just don't know you the way I do.  Yes, well you get yourself well and get right back there.  I miss seeing you every time I walk by the.... place you tend to be. [_calls:_] Niles.  _We now see another hospital corridor.  It is the birth ward. Niles is looking through a window at all the newborns._

speaker: Frasier
text: [_calls:_] Niles. [_enters_] Niles, what are you doing?

speaker: Niles
text: Looking at these babies.  I can't help wondering if I made the right decision.

speaker: Frasier
text: Niles...

speaker: Niles
text: Oh look at them, they're healthy, beautiful, lovable...

speaker: Frasier
text: Flammable!

speaker: Niles
text: How can I deny myself this experience?  Maybe I'm more ready for parenthood than I thought.  _The cab driver from Scene Two enters from a room across the hallway. She is carrying her baby._

speaker: Arleen
text: Hey, what are you guys doing here?

speaker: Frasier
text: How funny running into you, and this must be...

speaker: Arleen
text: Yes, little Nathan.  Oh, I'm so glad I ran into you.  We both want to thank you guys again.  So, would one of you like to hold him?

speaker: Niles
text: Yes. [_he is thrilled to hold him and does so_] Shush! [_Nathan starts crying_] Why shouldn't you cry?  Everything's so new to you, so much to do, a life to live.

speaker: Arleen
text: No, you've got his leg pinned back.

speaker: Arleen
text: Well, see you guys. Say hi to your dad for me. [_leaves_]

speaker: Niles
text: Perhaps I made the right decision.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, I think so.  Ready to go?

speaker: Niles
text: Uh-huh.  _Frasier exits as Niles carries on staring at the newborns.  END OF ACT TWO_
